segments.text: Okay, this is Ron Shorn interviewing Torrance Johnson in Boulder, Colorado on October 20th, 1993.
Torrance, for the record, could you give us your full name?
Torrance V. Johnson.
And when and where were you born?
In New York, December 1st, 1944.
New York City?
Actually on Long Island, Rockville Center.
When did you first get interested in astronomy?
Oh, I was interested in astronomy as a kid.
Actually, I was more interested in dinosaurs.
But as I got interested in physics and things like that, I got interested in telescopes and astronomy along with that.
I used to go to the planetarium in both New York when we lived there, and we also lived out in San Francisco.
And folks used to take me to the planetarium every year.
every month for new shows.
So I've been interested pretty much since I was a small kid.
Where did you go to undergraduate school?
Washington University in St. Louis.
And what was your major?
Physics with a pretty strong minor in geology and geophysics.
Why did you pick that university?
It's halfway between Long Island and San Francisco, of course.
Well, we moved around when I was a kid.
My father was in the Coast Guard, and
About the time I was in high school, he retired from the Coast Guard and went back to school at Mississippi Southern University, which was, Mississippi was where my mother came from.
And when time came around to get to college, we were looking for good scholarships and things, and I'd never been to the Midwest before.
Washington U had a very strong program.
going out aggressively recruiting smart people from different parts of the country.
We were the first class that had more than 50% streetcar college kids from the local parts of St. Louis.
Did you take any astronomy as an undergraduate?
No, there wasn't an astronomy department at Washington U.
What we had was some physicists who were engaged in different types of what is generally called astronomy.
We had people interested in X-ray, gamma ray, and the emerging field of infrared astronomy at that time.
In fact, my interest in that type of astronomy was piqued by doing a senior project for Dr. Friedman there.

And what I did was researched a lot of the early work in infrared astronomy being done out at Caltech by Gary Neugebauer and Bruce Murray, and tried to help think about how they might set up some similar infrared work at Washington U.
When did you get your bachelor's degree?
And then where did you go for your graduate work?
I went out to Caltech and I was influenced partially by those working and reading with those papers on infrared astronomy.
I thought it was sort of neat to couple the ideas of astronomy and geology together and I was interested in the infrared telescopic work that was being done out at Caltech.
And right at that time I sent my
my application into the physics department, since I was in the physics department.

And I wasn't really good enough in physics to get into the Caltech physics department, but they bumped it over to geology, where Bruce was trying to put together a program of people working quantitatively with using astronomy and physics to understand planetary problems.
What did you do your doctoral dissertation on, and who under?
I was a student of Bruce Murray's at Caltech from the time I got there, and I worked on doing spectrophotometric studies of the Galilean satellites.
Bruce was quite good at, I think, handing over really good problems to his students.
I had a survey course from Bruce where he kind of laid out a lot of things about solar system astronomy to us,
And he said, gee, nothing's known about the Galilean satellites of Jupiter.
Why don't you work on that?
And what he had done was asked me to review for the class everything that was known about the Galilean satellites.
I accomplished that in about 15 minutes at the time.
Now we can have a whole conference on one aspect of Io for a week.
And the other thing that came together at that time was that Tom McCord was in the midst of his thesis work there also working for Bruce Murray.
And he had developed and built his dual beam photometer for doing multispectral observations at anywhere from 12 to 24 different wavelengths of different areas on the moon.
And Bruce thought it would be a neat idea to apply that instrumentation
to the Galilean satellite studies.
So I started working with Tom, helping him with his lunar studies, and I got involved in lunar astronomy at that point also.

And then as Tom phased out of that, went to MIT, I took over the equipment, if you will, and started working on that for a whole apparition doing spectrophotometric studies of the Galilean satellites.
When did you complete your PhD, or when did they throw you out?
I left for MIT in 1969 to take up a post-doctoral job with Tom McCord, who'd set up a lab there.
And so I concentrated on getting my thesis published, which I actually got a little bit of it published as opposed to some people.
and continuing to expand the work that Tom and I had started on both the moon, satellites, and asteroids with his group that Tom had started at MIT.
So I arrived there in the fall of 69.
How did you make that connection with McCartan?
Well, as I said, I've been working with him.
He was, in essence, my mentor amongst the graduate students at Caltech.
He was a couple of years ahead of me, and I kind of apprenticed myself to him to learn about the equipment side of the business, working with lunar observations.
And then when he went to MIT, I spent another year finishing up my thesis, and he offered me a postdoctoral position at MIT.
OK, how long did you keep this postdoc, and what did you do?
Well, what we worked on during that period of time, the period was 1969 until about 1971.
So it was a little over a year and a half at MIT.
And during that period, we worked on a number of interesting things, extending the spectrophotometric studies we've been doing to Saturn satellites.
and the rings of Saturn, and to asteroids.
And there were a lot of people that are major players in that game that were students of Tom's and that I worked with.
Clark Chapman was doing asteroid spectrophotometry.
And let's see, I was trying to think.
Gloria Lubofsky was doing a lot of stuff on the rings of Saturn at that time.
And I got involved with both of those partially kind of
helping bring them along with using the equipment and data reduction and so forth in the same way that Tom had helped me.
What did you do after that post-doc?
Well, times were tough then.
If you remember, in 1970, 71, we were hitting the big post-Apollo downswing, and academic positions were as scarce as hen's teeth.
And so I started looking around, getting my resume out.
I actually looked at taking a job with...
what became the, you know, there was an environmental office that was set up back then.
I've even forgotten what they called it.
I went down to Washington to interview with those guys.
And I went out to, I wrote to
JPL for one of these NRC, National Research Council, postdoctoral positions, which were postdoctoral but paid a lot better than the academic postdoc positions at that time.
So ultimately I ended up doing a NRC postdoc at JPL and getting involved in some research at JPL that then led to getting a job offer at JPL when that ran out.
What did you do with that NRC thing?
How long was it and what did you do?
I think that was a period of two years.
I'd have to check.
Let's see.
I just got my 20th year pin at JPL.
So I was, I guess, officially hired in around December of 93.
So it was a two year.
I'm sorry.
So I must have been hired in December of 73.
And so it was a two year postdoctoral thing.
And during that period of time, we started doing, I worked a bit with Dennis Madsen on infrared studies of asteroids.
And one of the major studies that we started at that point was doing a little bit of laboratory work, which I hadn't done before.
Frasier Finale was at JPL.

And he and I started doing some of the first spectral observations of meteorite samples to see if we could explain the properties of these very dark, spectrally featureless asteroids that we were beginning to come up with from Chapman's spectrophotometric survey.
Now, you've been at JPL since then until today, and just in general, what have you been doing the last 20 years?
Well, let's see.
I guess during my general tenure at JPL, things have kind of split into two general areas.
One of them is continuation of telescopic research,
and the other is spacecraft instrumentation and experiments in about equal measure.
Over the years at JPL, we've continued to work on spectral imaging techniques on everything from lunar things to spacecraft images from Voyager and Galileo.
In the last decade or so, we've gotten quite involved in infrared astronomy of Jupiter's satellite Io.

After we discovered the volcanoes on Io with Voyager, we realized that we probably had all along been seeing the infrared signature of those volcanoes in the ground-based infrared data on Io and set up a program to monitor and measure the heat energy coming from Io.

So I worked on the Voyager imaging team through all of its encounters with Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune, and I got involved in the mid-'70s with a lot of NASA studies on future missions, particularly to the Jupiter system, as a result of the work that I'd done.
Don Hunton had a committee on atmospheric entry probes that I was a member of, and then I was a member of...
Jim Van Allen's committee, which ultimately recommended the Jupiter Orbiter Probe Mission, which became the Galileo Mission.
And after that got started, I became the project scientist on that, which has sort of occupied me since 1978, about half of my time, more or less.
Okay, now I'm going to switch the subject.
Do you consider planetary astronomy, or planetary science, I realize that some people make a difference, but I'll call it planetary astronomy...
Is it part of astronomy, in your opinion?
Some of it is parts of astronomy.

I think it is almost becoming a separate discipline in itself in the sense of the study of planets involving a lot of the major physical and even biological sciences directed toward studies in the planetary context.
When you started in this game in the 60s,
and early 70s, did you feel second rate compared to, quote, real, unquote, astronomers like the ones at Caltech and Palomar models?
We had a lot of that type of feeling.
At Caltech, it was a little bit more like the traditional frictions between the messier sciences like chemistry and geology compared to the purer sciences like astronomy, mathematics, and physics.
And I think those of us that worked for Bruce, we didn't feel second rate, but we knew that a lot of the real astronomers felt that we were second rate.
I think we felt a bit more like Mavericks.
We knew we were good.
We knew we were applying techniques that had never been applied to interesting problems before.
It was kind of interesting.
You'd run into people on the mountain.
You're doing something, and they'd say, what, you're doing that on a planet?
And you'd describe your equipment to them, and by God, your equipment and the techniques you were using would be better than what they were using.
So it was a fair amount of cross-fertilization.
Mostly, I'd say the rivalry was more friendly than not.
You think...
Do you think today that planetary astronomy and planetary astronomers are accepted by other astronomers or do you think they're still considered a little second rate because they're not
megaparsecs away?
I think there's always, I think they're more accepted.
I think there's a lot less of why are you looking at a planet?
Why are you even worried about it?
We used to get those questions.
Some of that was just ignorance and compartmentalization amongst the pure astronomers.
I think there was a lot of feeling that with the discovery of Pluto and a few of these other things that it was sort of like the field had been put to bed.
We knew about the planets.
They were close and so forth.

And I think that feeling went away gradually and probably not gone completely at the moment with the discoveries that were made by the spacecraft and ground-based astronomy in the last 20 years, revitalizing a field.
It's a bit like celestial mechanics.
I mean, I always felt celestial mechanics was a dead field until people like Peter Golreich started playing games, and now chaos is big in it.
I mean, it's bigger than it was when Descartes and those guys were working on things.
There actually is some stuff that Laplace or Lagrange didn't discover.
Could you take a minute or two and just give me your subjective opinion of how planetary astronomy has changed from when you began in it to now?
Obvious things like size, for example.
Well, there are
Size is the thing that comes to mind, particularly sitting here at the DPS meeting, is that there's just a massive amount more people working in the field.
And I think this mimics the growth of astronomy out of phase by maybe a few decades also, is that when the DPS started and when I began in the field, you could...
literally fit most of the planetary astronomy and planetary geologists, if you wanted to, you know, around the table in a relatively large room.
And now the hotel is overflowing with people all working in the area.
That's been one of the changes.
I think the other change is the diversity of techniques being applied these days, all the way from X-ray to X-band, if you will.
A lot of things that were just dreams that we had, and considering things that we might apply to planetary studies,
in the 60s are absolutely routine now.
Super high-resolution spectroscopy, infrared imaging.
Spacecraft are the obvious things.
Spacecraft make big breakthrough sets of observations.
There's no other way to make.
But even amongst the techniques used in near-Earth space and ground-based, I think that I'm kind of overwhelmed by the number of different clever ideas
theoretically and experimentally that people were applying to the problem these days.
Do you ever get annoyed when some popular level book claims that space probes discovered everything we know about the solar system?
I tell you, we fought that with the press on Voyager so hard and with so little success.
It was extremely frustrating because

Most of the people on the science teams on Voyager were well aware that they were standing on the shoulders of a generation or two of people looking and studying these things from the ground and the theoretical underpinnings.
Perhaps the most egregious example of that is the business of water ice in the outer solar system, which was...

hinted at very strongly in work back in the 50s done by Kuiper and others, a simple one and two broadband IR observation showing that the reflectance of the satellites was very low and hints that the albedos of the satellites were very high, although the issue of the albedos, of course, was controversial because we didn't have good radii.
But, you know, by the early 70s, the ground-based spectra were incontrovertible.
Water ice existed in the outer solar system on most of these surfaces.
We began to get a few good radii.
The albedos were high.

This was established context by the time Voyager visited the Galilean satellites in 79, and yet to this day you still see after Voyager got there, we then knew that there was water ice on the surface of these things.
And
Everybody who talked with the press from the science community always kept making that point.
But it's a cultural thing, and you're probably aware of this in the work that you've done.
Well, hi, Spinrad.
And Toby and I get a big bang out of Viking discovered, or whatever, Mariner discovered water on Mars.
But the best one was when Viking 1 lander landed, there was a headline in a Houston paper, one of the Houston papers.
It said, Viking proves Mars is red.
And Andy Young was so mad that he wrote off a letter.
He says, well, why didn't they say Viking proves grass is green or something like that?
I'm surprised at that from Andy, what he should have said.
Viking didn't prove Mars was red, and it isn't anyway.
What's the best piece of work you've done, in your opinion?
Oh, Lord, that's I've worked on a number of things.

I think in terms of sort of team science, I'm proudest of having worked to get what I think are much better observations of the satellites throughout the history of the Voyager mission than would have been done if we hadn't had myself and a lot of other good people working very hard to get good satellite observations.
These things are
quite difficult to plan in detail and take a lot of hard work.
In terms of specific scientific type things, I feel myself quite attached to Io and the way Carl maybe feels himself attached to Mars.
And I think that my efforts over the years have done a lot toward illuminating what's really going on on Io, although nobody would pretend to really
understand it now.
The work I've done with Dennis Mattson trying to understand the heat flow from Iowa I think is perhaps some of the most fundamental work on that.
Where do you get your ideas on what to do?
Is it because NASA puts out a request for proposals to study EO or is it because you have an idea that you think you want to do?
In your personal experience, what's the mix there?
My personal experience is that it's almost entirely internally driven, but that's because the environment, at least up until the current moment, has allowed that.

In other words, we've been fortunate to be in a situation where we can come up with interesting concepts in planetary science, and there is, in fact, the structure of interest at NASA and other funding agencies to pursue that.
we haven't had to go out and look to find exactly what they're interested in in order to get the funding.
And that started as my tenure at Caltech was supported.
You're talking about the meteorites.
Reminded me of the...
Reminded me of the...
The first asteroid that we got a really good spectrum of that had a really good absorption band in it was Vesta.
And it's still the most pronounced absorption band on any asteroid that was observed.
And I think it probably holds the record for the fastest identification of any planetary piece of remote spectral sensing.
And the reason is it happened right after the first Apollo sample returns.

And the data from the Vesta run, which I'd been involved in, Lebowski, MJ Elias, and a few other people, along with Tom McCord, was wrapped up on tape and waiting, sitting at MITPAL at MIT, the Planetary Astronomy Lab.
And Tom was off working with their initial sample returns with John Adams, taking spectra, the return samples, comparing it with lunar samples.
And we had in hand right at that time, we talked to some of my older colleagues who dealt with headquarters and the government in the pre-Apollo era, in the Apollo era.
I think you'll find a slightly different tinge, at least anecdotally.
People felt that a lot of the people at NASA were not well-trained in their fields and didn't know what good science were.
By the time I was interacting with them,

partially as a result of criticisms like that from the Academy and other places, the people at headquarters who actually were involved in directing the programs connected with planetary work I feel were
in fact, well equipped to discern what was good and were working very hard to develop peer review techniques and so forth.

That doesn't mean everything went swimmingly, but I didn't run into the types of things that I at least heard stories about, like somebody in there had been trained as an agronomist or something like that who was suddenly trying to make a whole bunch of decisions about what instruments should go on some Mars mission.
There have been three big funding crunches in NASA's history.
One was the one you referred to earlier, 1973 or so.
There was another one around 81 or 82, and it looks like we're going to get another one right now.
What effect does this have on the field, and in particular on the younger guys who don't have a reputation yet?
Well, the 80-81 crunch was basically, I believe, coincident with the Nixon administration and the Reagan administration coming in.
And some of the feeling on the part of some of the parts of that administration that NASA was either irrelevant or science was.
I'm not sure which.
which gradually worked its way out, but the emphasis on the shuttle was very strong then.
The shuttle was having problems.
I was not personally affected too badly by that in my professional career in the sense that we had to worry about not getting funded.
We were in the midst of trying to get Galileo built at that time.
The way we were affected was that it had a tremendously negative effect on the long-term stretch out of the Galileo program.
The shuttle should have been flying in the early 80s, and it wasn't.
And that affected Galileo and all subsequent planetary and space missions.
So the 80s were a continual struggle, if you will, to play catch up from that.
And given that those stretch outs cost large amounts of money, the money available for research outside of the mission areas also decreased during that period of time.
And that's where you first started feeling that there was a tremendous pressure on some of the younger people in the field.
It became very difficult then and has remained difficult to get permanent positions.
A lot of people have been in rotating post-doctoral positions and unsolved money positions even when they do get a job.

uh it's been said that every year the dps got lots of young eager faces at it but um somebody else also remarked that well they're not all the same eager faces and they're all looking for a job and uh that that's been kind of a pattern since that period in the early 80s in my my impression uh if a sharp person who just got their bachelor's degree came up to you and said gee i really want to be a planetary astronomer what would you say to him or her
I guess my first-order response would be a relatively elitist one.
There's always room at the top.
If that's what you're really interested in and you're good, you can find a place.
That doesn't mean it's the best place to make a career, best place to make money.
There might be something the person is equally interested in.
Well, of course, it's a similar situation to the one that astronomers in general went for 100 years.
There were very few jobs in astronomy, and of course,
about the money crunch before there was the shuttle, Apollo was the villain, and now it's the space station, and there's always something.
So that part at least is constant.

If you listen to the tenor of the discussions at NASA night here at the DPS, I don't see any, the names have changed and some of the issues have changed, but the general tenor of the discussions sound an awful lot like the ones I heard back in the 70s.
Where do you think planetary astronomy today would be without NASA's money?
the stuff it's given over the last 30 years or so.
Well, I think that goes back to your point about the way planetary astronomy was viewed in the previous decades.
I think it would be a relatively small offshoot of, if you quote Will, regular astronomy, dealing with global properties of objects and occasional curiosities, such as Io or the rotation of Mercury.
I think the infusion of support for studying the solar system that started with the Apollo program and NASA and, well, the space program generally.
I mean, starting with Sputnik, really, if you want to put it that way.
By the way, my high school career was altered somewhat by what was an old Title IV funds post-Sputnik.
You know, we got to get, you know, better scientists.
We got good equipment, and I got more interested in physics as a result of that type of thing.
But I don't think there would be a field of planetary astronomy or planetary science as we know it today other than without NASA's infusion of resources.
There would probably be a single faculty member or maybe two faculty members in a couple of the larger departments dealing with this, more or less as it was back in the 50s and 40s.
Today, the Division for Planetary Sciences of the American Astronomical Society exists, and it has an official journal, namely Icarus.
Are these two developments good, bad, inevitable?
What's your feelings?

I think you've got to put it in the context of what was happening generally in the 60s and 70s as they developed this entire field of planetary studies, and I won't restrict it strictly to planetary astronomy.
There was a feeling in a number of the classical professional societies that they needed to take account of this discipline in some way.
And this was done in a number of different ways.
In the astronomy community, the Division for Planetary Science was formed.
Some of the same players were responsible for forming a section in the American Geophysical Union.
NASA has a journal called JGR Planets.
Yes, a piece of the traditional JGR journal.
The GSA did something similar, but not Geological Society of America, which was not quite as autonomous.
Each one of these responses was a little different.
The Division for Planetary Sciences and the AAS rapidly became almost entirely autonomous from the AAS.
It, in effect, is a separate society, in my opinion.
Whereas in the American Geophysical Union, the planetology section remains a relatively small but active section within the union as a whole and has its sessions with the major meeting of the AGU.
It's not an autonomous thing.
I think that's the same pattern as the GSA also.
I think all of these activities were a logical response to the number of people and the number of ideas working in the field.

Just to stick in yet a third thing that I've kind of looked at over the years, there was a major perturbation and difficulty with trying to figure out where the tremendous amount of information developed from the Apollo samples
the geochemistry and the subsequent work on meteorites should go in all of this.
If you go back to the early days of 69 and the Apollo era,
A lot of the early results were presented at AGU meetings and DPS meetings.
In fact, some of those people were founders.
Ed Anders was our second president, I believe, of the DPS, or chairman of the DPS.
And Anders and the people working in geochemistry haven't been involved
in detail with DPS for many years since then.
What happened was that as a result of the Apollo sample studies, there in effect grew up a society without a society, which was the Lunar Planetary Science Conference down at Houston.
It started out as the Lunar Science Conference, and it started out strictly as a meeting of the PIs on the Apollo program.
And that's grown into yet another different accommodation for communication in this area.
The Meteoritical Society has a similar type of role.
So you rarely see much rock and meteorite work presented at the DPS or the AGU anymore.
These other areas tend to have subsumed that function.
So the fractionation continues.
Well, I think the fractionation existed by 1972 and hasn't changed too much since then, although the boundaries of these Venn diagrams overlap.
People work on doing joint sessions successfully sometimes, and there are a number of parts of the community that tend to go to two or more of these types of meetings.
Do you have much contact with astronomers who work on stars, galaxies, and things like that?
Very little, and I think that's one of the negative effects of this fractionation, as you will.

In the early days of my career, I went to AAS meetings occasionally when they had sessions on planetary astronomy, and I felt that was quite valuable, particularly in terms of changing information about techniques and so forth of observing.
But with the growth of these other things in the types of areas that I'm working in, there are two AGU meetings per year, a DPS meeting, a lunar meeting, to say nothing of international meetings.
And to try to also, and I've drifted more into, if you will, the geophysical side of some of these things rather than the pure observational astronomy.
So I've tended to put the weight of where I operate more on that side, and it's taken me more away from astronomy in a pure astronomical sense.
Do you think the fact that there's now a lot of interest among stellar astronomers in formation of other solar systems offers a chance to maybe bring at least those people and DPS types together?
I think we've already seen a bit of that.
The fact that we don't actually have another solar system yet identified to form the nucleus or focus of a new field of studying extrasolar solar systems
has limited that, but at a number of major meetings over the years, in the past few years, we've seen people of both of those disciplines coming together to worry about this problem.
I kind of see this as a cyclic type of thing in history, and I think that the information and the techniques of stellar astronomy are now to the point where
They are gathering data and the theoretical constructs are beginning to become available that are now relevant to really planetary issues in other solar systems.

I don't think that will actually happen in a major way until one or more real extrasolar systems are identified and we actually have some physical data on one or more planets that aren't in the solar system.
You were saying that there was a lot of talk and discussion about voluntary types splitting off from the AAS.
Would you continue to do that?
I was the secretary treasurer of the DPS for a term back in the 70s.
I've forgotten the exact years of my office and got involved in a lot of the council meetings and so forth and the DPS committee meetings.
And there were at least a couple of cycles that I remember not too clearly as to exact dates where the membership proposed that it might be a good idea to split away from the AAS entirely.
And the options were usually form a separate society, get involved with some other society, such as the GSA or the AGU, Geological Society of America.
And those, I believe that those discussions were fueled by a number of different parallel types of problems.

One of them had to do with sort of logistics, whether we were being well served by the parent organization in terms of where our dues were going, what we were getting for it other than getting abstract published in the BAAS.
and whether the discipline was relevant enough to the AAS.
The other, if you will, more intellectually reputable point of view, I think, was that the society, the DPS at that time, was already...
drawing a broader community of people to its meetings than astronomers.
There are a lot of people who didn't feel themselves to be astronomers.
They'd come out of geology departments like myself.
I never felt particularly strongly about that.
I felt that it was more a matter of pragmatic convenience as to where a good place for professional society to be was.
There are also issues about the journal, and I think that
probably people that were involved with the genesis of the relationship of the DPS to ICRIS could tell you more about that.
But there was a major stumbling block, if you will, I think, in the early days is that the membership of the DPS didn't feel that the AAS journals were serving their interest.
This is a problem that you mentioned, the AGU.

In fact, a similar set of discussions has led very recently to the formation of a section of the Journal of Geophysical Research devoted to planets because it was felt that that would better serve the membership that was interested in planetary science.
Whether that works or not remains to be seen.
Do you think planetary astronomers have done a good job of selling themselves, A, to the public, and B, to the United States Congress?
Well, I don't know in terms of selling themselves.
Again, I tend to review these things more in the context of science as a political and policy issue within the government as a whole.
I think in terms of catching public interest and having Congress sympathetic to the types of research we're doing, we have a slightly easy job, actually.
I think that people relate to the exploration motif and looking at new worlds
They also relate to discovering things about black holes.
I think you can get too far over on this.
If it's not relevant to me today to exploit for some sort of economic benefit, it isn't going to interest Congress, it isn't going to interest the public.
I find the exact opposite.

And I think that it's sort of interesting in some way that our relativistic astrophysicists find themselves in a position of being, it's as easy to get the public interested in their thing as it is interested in a lunar base, which you might think is much more relevant to a lot of people's thoughts.
From your experiences, from the general public you've met, what do they think of planetary astronomy?
Practically everybody I've ever met
in a social context that was reasonably well-educated has been very interested in it.
They find out you're an astronomer, find out you work with planets.
You always get lots of questions, very eager questions, some of them naive, some of them somewhat ignorant.
And occasionally they, what's your sign?
Did you say you were working in astrology?
Type of questions.
I find that the educated public in general very interested in that.
I've rarely gotten an extremely hostile response as, you know, what the hell are you wasting the government's money with that for?
I think a lot of people are worried and frequently misinformed about the total amount of money we spend on these types of things.

I think that's one of the problems that science and basic science in general have, that they see the shiny rockets out on the launch pads and think that a large fraction of the national treasury must be pouring into those things to satisfy our curiosity.
And, of course, these programs are substantial, but they're nowhere near up in even the top five or six government spending categories.
Most people don't realize that, but as taxpayers, they're concerned about whether we're doing the right thing.
I frequently get questioned about that, usually in a fairly non-confrontational way.
Do you think the spectacular results that we've gotten out of the solar system in the last 30 or 40 years, do you think that's really changed the way anybody thinks about anything?
That's more of a question for a sociologist or anthropologist.
I think it has.
I think everybody now relates to the Earth as a whole picture as seen by Apollo pictures and other pictures, you know, a globe.
I think that if you just think about...
If you show a picture of an object to somebody now with a bunch of impact craters in it, people understand the impacts of...
bodies into other bodies over 4.6 billion years is something that's happened.
Most people that are involved with following science and astronomy at all sort of have that in their background knowledge now.
Back in the 50s and 60s, you probably couldn't find one person in a thousand that knew that the holes in the moon were created by meteorites slamming into them or asteroid or cometary debris.
And at that time, people didn't even really know the length of time or the time scales that these things had been done over.
I think there's a tremendous amount of shared knowledge about our history in the solar system that has crept into the public consciousness without anybody really noticing it.
It's not just a matter of flashy pictures in the textbooks.
How much, if any, negative effect on public interest and public funding of planetary astronomy
How much of a negative impact on those two things do you think our failure to find any evidence of life anywhere else in the solar system except particularly not on Mars has had?
I think that's been overblown a bit, just as I felt that the original raison d'etre of Mars exploration being nothing but the search for life was also overblown.

I think people are somewhat disappointed, but I think that in fact, again, in terms of this kind of shared cultural knowledge of where we are, who we are, and what the solar system is, they now know that there aren't little green men on Mars, and they're not...
Most of them.
Most of them do.
The others are uneducable, so that's... And I think people were disappointed, but...
I think that's taking the universe as it is, rather than wanting it to be the way somebody might make it.

I think that interest, if you will, the interest that was wrapped up in the search for life on Mars now has shifted to perhaps more subtle problems of the history of life on the Earth, the effects of impact on evolution on the Earth.

the origins of life itself in terms of the chemistry brought in by comets and impacting debris, and the possibility of there having been false starts at getting life going in other environments, looking for fossils on Mars, if you will.
I find people still very interested in these things, interested in the concept of other worlds and other solar systems beyond the solar system that might harbor life
Quite frankly, I don't think I've ever had anybody come up to me and say, the solar system, the planetary program should be shut down now.
We know there isn't life on Mars.
That's all we were doing it for.
I never really run into much of that reaction.
Looking at your crystal ball a minute, what do you see for the future of planetary astronomy and planetary science for the next 10 years or so?
I think it's in a mode of consolidation.
Now, right at the moment, you could say we're in a... You could be very negative right at the moment.
I personally feel the situation with respect to leadership in Washington at this instant is quite bad.
I don't think that the right resources...
I don't think we've got realism in the resources and constraints and plans for planetary work.
But I also think there's a very large...
a base of firm understanding of what we should be doing that will carry the country through to a reasonable continuity ultimately.
And what I see is sort of consolidation.
I see a lot of
work exploiting what we can do from the ground and from Earth-based astronomy, that's Earth orbital astronomy.
That has really grown.
It's easier to do than the big major outer planets missions.
I see that there's the emphasis on small missions.
I think we are going to have more small missions.
I think that they're not going to be as
mind-blowing and revealing as a few of the big missions have been, but they're going to be addressing very relevant, very interesting questions.
We'll be able to deal with that.

So I think if you think about it in DPS context, we're going to have a lot of nitty-gritty, hard science returns from a number of ways and fewer of the big breakthroughs, oh, we never knew that that was going on there again.
But I think that's inevitable with the maturing of any field is that...
I've always liked a comment that Carl Sagan made many years ago, is you only explore the solar system for the first time once.
So you don't think the field is mined out by any extent?
Oh, no, no.
Any more than the field of geology was mined out in the 19th century.
Last few years, there's been a lot of attention and certainly a lot of publicity directed towards making planetary astronomy practical.
And I think things like ozone layer studies...
global warming, killer asteroids and comets.
Do you think that's been overdone, or do you think we ought to do everything we can?
Or do you think if it's good science, so what if it gets publicity?
Your personal opinion.
I think we ought to let people know what's relevant about our science.
You always face the issue of over-hyping something and getting out on a limb and stating things that are really warped in terms of their perspective.
Not true.
In the worst case, actually, you know, dropping into charlatanism, trying to sell something on a flashy basis that has no substance.
I would not accuse...
anybody of that in a major way in the instances you just measured.
I believe there's a firm basis to most of those types of studies, which is important to people.
